body.p: Once the inventory is ready, the next step is to modify the group variables to match your environment. To do so, you need to edit the file group_vars/vars. The variables can be defined in any order but for the sake of clarity they have been divided into sections.
All VMware-related variables are mandatory and are described in Table 5.

row.entry: IP or hostname of the vCenter appliance

Username to log in to the vCenter appliance. It might include a domain, for example, 'administrator@vsphere.local'. Note: The corresponding password is stored in a separate file (group_vars/vault) with the variable named vcenter_password.
Name of the datacenter where the environment will be provisioned

Username to log into the VMs. It needs to match the one from the VM Template, so unless you have created an user, you must use 'root'. Note: The corresponding password is stored in a separate file (group_vars/vault) with the variable named vm_password.
Name of the RHEL VM Template to be use. Note that this is the name from a vCenter perspective, not the hostname.
Name of the Windows 2016 VM Template to use. Note that this is the name from a vCenter perspective, not the hostname.

vCenter folder to deploy the VMs. If you do not wish to deploy in a particular folder, the value should be /. Note: If you want to deploy in a specific folder, you need to create this folder in the inventory of the selected datacenter before starting the deployment.
List of datastores to be used, in list format, i.e. ['Datastore1','Datastore2'...]. This or these datastore(s) must exist before you run the playbooks.
UNIX® name of the second disk for the Docker VMs. Typically /dev/sdb
UNIX name of the partition of the second disk for the Docker VMs. Typically /dev/sdb1

Version of the vSphere plugin for Docker. The default is 0.20 which is the latest version at the time of writing this document. The version of the plugin should match the version of the vSphere Installation Bundle (VIB) that you installed on the ESXi servers.

body.p: All network-related variables are mandatory and are described in Table 7.

row.entry: Name of the device, for RHEL this is typically ens192 and it is recommended to leave it as is.
IP address of the gateway to be used
List of DNS servers to be used, in list format, i.e. ['10.10.173.1','10.10.173.2'...]
Domain name for your Virtual Machines
List of NTP servers to be used, in list format, i.e. ['1.2.3.4','0.us.pool.net.org'...]

body.p: All Docker-related variables are mandatory and are described in Table 8.

row.entry: Note: This is a private link to your Docker EE subscription. This should be kept secret and defined in group_vars/vault. The value for docker_ee_url is the URL documented at the following address: https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/linux/docker-ee/rhel/.
Version of your RHEL OS, such as 7.4. The playbooks were tested with RHEL 7.3. and RHEL 7.4.
Version of the Docker DTR you wish to install. You can use a numeric version or latest for the most recent one. The playbooks were tested with 2.3.3. and 2.4.0.
Version of the Docker UCP you wish to install. You can use a numeric version or latest for the most recent one. The playbooks were tested with UCP 2.2.3. and 2.2.4.
Directory in the NFS server that will be mounted in the DTR nodes and that will host your Docker images.
Full path to your Docker EE license file (it should be stored in your Ansible host).License file is available from the Docker Store
Username of the administrator user for UCP and DTR, typically admin. Note: The corresponding password is stored in a separate file (group_vars/vault) with the variable named ucp_password.
If true, the creation of Windows 2016 worker nodes will be actioned. The default value is false.

body.p: All Monitoring-related variables are described in Table 9. The variables determine the versions of various monitoring software tools that are used and it is recommended that the values given below are used.

row.entry: The name of the volume which will be used to store the monitoring data. The volume is created using the vsphere docker volume plugin.
The size of the volume which will hold the monitoring data. The exact syntax is dictated by the vSphere Docker Volume plugin. The default value is 10GB.

body.p: Logspout is a log router for Docker containers that runs inside Docker. It attaches to all containers on a host, then routes their logs to the central logging VM. All Logspout-related variables are described in Table 10.

row.entry: ‘master’ More details on Logspout are available later in this document.

body.p: All Environment-related variables should be here. All of them are described in the Table 11 below.

row.entry:
Dictionary containing all environment variables. It contains three entries described below. Please leave empty the proxy related settings if not required:
http_proxy: HTTP proxy URL, such as 'http://15.184.4.2:8080'. This variable defines the HTTP proxy url if your environment is behind a proxy.
https_proxy: HTTP proxy URL, such as 'http://15.184.4.2:8080'. This variable defines the HTTPS proxy url if your environment is behind a proxy.
no_proxy: List of hostnames or IPs that don't require proxy, such as 'localhost,127.0.0.1,.cloudra.local,10.10.174.'
